author: natemcmaster
body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------

On macOS 10.13, make this file and `chmod +x sample.ps1` it.

```powershell
#!/usr/bin/env pwsh
param(
    [string[]]$Names
)

Write-Host "Names = $($Names -join ':')"
Write-Host "args = $($args -join ':')"
```

On command line, invoke the script from bash and then from pwsh
```
bash
./sample.ps1 -name 1,2,3
./sample.ps1 -name 1, 2, 3

pwsh
./sample.ps1 -name 1,2,3
./sample.ps1 -name 1, 2, 3
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

Same behavior invoking the .ps1 script from bash or pwsh.

```none
./sample.ps1 -name 1,2,3
Names = 1:2:3
args =

./sample.ps1 -name 1, 2, 3
Names = 1:2:3
args =
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
bash
$ ./sample.ps1 -name 1,2,3
Names = 1,2,3
args =

$ ./sample.ps1 -name 1, 2, 3
Names = 1,
args = 2,:3
```
```
pwsh
$ ./sample.ps1 -name 1,2,3
Names = 1:2:3
args =
$ ./sample.ps1 -name 1, 2, 3
Names = 1:2:3
args =
```

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
Can't find the issue, but this was discussed due to differences in how `pwsh -f` and `pwsh -c` parse arguments and is currently `by-design`.  Workaround to get the behavior you want is to use:

```none
#!/usr/bin/env pwsh -c
```

title: Invoking ps1 script from bash doesn't parse comma-separated arg to string[]
